newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Gencor still studying Mozambique titanium deposit.
newsitem.headline: Gencor still studying Mozambique titanium deposit.

text.p: Gencor Ltd will decide whether to go ahead with a $500 million mineral sands project in Mozambique after completion of a detailed feasibility study late in 1998, the company said on Tuesday.
Project leader John Dudaf told Reuters Gencor had recently started the second phase of its probe into mining the Moebase mineral sands deposit 550 km northwest of Beira.
Initial drilling results indicated reserves of some 20 million tonnes of titanium dioxide at the deposit.
"We are in a feasibility study stage and there is no way one would make a decision until the feasibility study is completed, and that would only be to the end of 1998," Dudaf said in an interview.
"We last reported our latest drilling results about a month ago, and we have got about 20 million tonnes of titanium dioxide, just about 80 percent of that is proven," Dudaf said.

With reserves of some 20 million tonnes of titanium dioxide, the Moebase deposit would be in the same league as South Africa's Richards Bay Minerals (RBM) -- one of the largest mineral sands mining operations in the world.
South Africa has the second largest reserves of titanium dioxide after Australia.
"Richards Bay has a reserve of 26 million tonnes, so it (Moebase) is very much in the world class for a deposit," Dudaf said.
Gencor, with its partners the Mozambican government and Caribbean-based Edlow Resources, planned to strip-mine the sand at Moebase to supply feedstock for a $230 million titanium smelter.
Titanium dioxide is used as a whitening agent, for instance in paints, and also as a welding rod cover and for ceramic components in the electronics industry.
Titanium alloy is used in aircraft, ships, spacecraft and missiles.
Local newspapers quoted Mozambican Prime Minister Pascal Mocumbi saying last week that the country would become a large exporter of titanium early in the next century.
South African papers speculated that his comments meant the project would go ahead but Dudaf was more cautious.
"Obviously the (Mozambican) government wants the project but...there are a lot of things we have to thrash out first before we make the decision," Dudaf said.
He said the feasiblity study was in two phases. One part of the study continued into 1997 while the detailed study would only be completed at the end of 1998.
"We are continuing with our drilling programme up there and we have commenced the detailed feasibility study," he said.
